snippet: Up to a million people are trapped inside Iraq’s second-largest city, where the brutal urban war of attrition is proving to be tougher than expected....
abstract: Battle to retake city of Mosul, Iraq, from Islamic State has settled into grinding war of attrition, with high numbers of security force and civilian casualties and immobile front line; up to one million people are trapped inside city, with food and water supplies running low; situation is likely to be among main national security issues facing Pres-elect Donald Trump when he takes office.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO, ERIC SCHMITT and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Istanbul; Eric Schmitt from Doha, Qatar; and Rukmini Callimachi from Erbil, Iraq. Falih Hassan contributed reporting from Baghdad, and an employee of The New York Times from Erbil.

lead_paragraph: Up to a million people are trapped inside Iraq’s second-largest city, where the brutal urban war of attrition is proving to be tougher than expected.

headline.main: Hungry, Thirsty and Bloodied in Battle to Retake Mosul From ISIS
headline.print_headline: Carnage, Hunger  and Fear in Iraq

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
